content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Identify the top headline in the World News section on BBC News and describe the region it is related to.  Please interact with https://www.bbc.com/news/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to find "World" link; maybe under "More" button
Action: Click 60
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to scroll page downward to look for “World” section with its top headline  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to keep scrolling further to reach the “World” section  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Still haven’t reached any heading titled “World”; need to continue scrolling.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: A navigation menu may have a “World” link; need to open it via “Open menu” button (label 220).  
Action: Click 220
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The opened menu shows a “News” button (347) that might reveal sub‑sections like “World”. Need to click it.  
Action: Click 347
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Within the expanded News menu, “World” itself isn’t yet visible; I should scroll downward in that overlay to look for a “World” link.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Close menu to reveal the normal top navigation where a “World” link should appear.  
Action: Click 220
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to look further down the homepage for a section titled “World”; scrolling should reveal it.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To quickly reach the overall World News page, I should open Google and search for “BBC World News” so I can click the direct /news/world link.  
Action: Google
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Enter search query “BBC World News” in the Google search box to reach the BBC World section quickly.  
Action: Type 1; BBC World News
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Google search leads to a CAPTCHA block. Better return to BBC page; go back to previous page (Google homepage) then again to earlier BBC page.  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to return to the BBC News page in earlier history to continue directly on the site.  
Action: GoBack
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I should scroll up to locate the “World” section heading on the BBC News homepage.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate the heading “World” on the homepage; scrolling farther up should reveal the World News section.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reach the very top of the News homepage where the secondary navigation bar (with “World”) should appear, so keep scrolling up.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “World” section is likely further down the homepage; scrolling downward should bring its heading into view.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The navigation overlay likely contains a direct “World” link; open the menu again to look for it.  
Action: Click 220
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The menu lists detailed “News” sub‑sections (UK, Africa, Asia, Europe, etc.). To reach the overall “World” news area quickly, I can open any of these regional links (e.g., Africa); once there, the breadcrumb/navigation bar usually contains a “World” link that will take me to the main World News page where the top headline is shown. I’ll start by opening the first regional link, “Africa”.  
Action: Click 2290
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The navigation bar shows caps for Israel‑Gaza War, War in Ukraine, regions etc., but a “World” root link isn’t listed; the “More” button (2455) may expand the category list where “World” could appear, leading to the World News page.  
Action: Click 2455
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The navigation bar lists region links but not the overall World link. The “More” button (2455) likely reveals additional navigation, potentially including “World”.  
Action: Click 2455
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Use the “News” link (2662) in the global navigation to open the main News homepage; there, a “World” sub‑section heading or link should appear.
Action: Click 2662
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The BBC News homepage likely contains a “World” section further down; scrolling downward should reveal a heading labelled “World” followed by its lead story.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “More” button (4379) likely expands the navigation bar and may reveal a link labeled “World”; that will take us to the main World News page whose top headline we need.  
Action: Click 4379

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The homepage probably contains a “World” news block further down; I should continue scrolling until the heading “World” appears.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The homepage still doesn’t show “World”; opening the site menu (button “Open menu” 4547) should list the “World” category directly.  
Action: Click 4547
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To reveal sub‑categories under News (likely including “World”), click the “News” button inside the open menu (element 4692).  
Action: Click 4692

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
